awd_titl_txt: ECR: BCSER: IRM: Building Big Data Capacity for Education and Social Science Research Communities Using Restricted Administrative Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will train and support diverse education and social science researchers to develop the skills necessary to effectively use large scale, privacy-protected administrative data to analyze core questions pertaining to STEM education. The goals are to provide technical training, methodological training, technical support for research project development, and community building for participants. The capacity building efforts leverage a successful research infrastructure, accessible data, and well-established history of innovative training to improve the technical and analytic readiness of diverse researchers. While the primary focus will be on the use of linked university research and education data in concert with public workforce information, the skills that learners will acquire will be broadly applicable to many large-scale data analysis projects. Systematic efforts will be made to connect training opportunities to the cultivation of research community, sustained proposal development efforts, and mechanisms that allow both to influence the growth of infrastructure and interdisciplinary capacity of STEM education researchers.

The institute will conduct two annual sets of training activities anchored by multi-day workshops hosted at the University of Michigan Institute for Social Research (ISR). ISR is the institutional home of the Institutes for Research on Innovation and Science (IRIS) and of the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR). The institute will target 150-165 diverse researchers from less research-intensive and minority-serving institutions. The project team will integrate the proposed capacity building activities with ICPSR summer institute curricula and community building activities while structuring these to align with deadlines for multiple external funding opportunities.  The primary data for the course will come from the Universities Measuring the Effects of Research on Innovation, Competitiveness and Science (UMETRICS) dataset, augmented by data on all enrolled students for a subset of participating campuses. These datasets will be integrated with public-use workforce data such as the Bureau of Labor Statistics Quarterly Census of Employments Statistics data and Post-Secondary Employment Outcomes project. Together, these data and associated training materials will provide participants with new tools and opportunities that offer additional avenues to develop research questions that build on their research interests.  In addition to building capacity in STEM education research, the project also addresses core components of NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution Big Idea by expanding access to tools and technologies to a research community.

The project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The availability of very large datasets containing information on scientific research and higher education is growing quickly, providing a great opportunity for people who study education and the social sciences (ESS). These datasets can be extremely valuable for research in ESS topics; for example, they can reveal what types of research teams are most productive, or what impact experience in research can have on a student?s long-term career trajectory. However, for ESS researchers with no experience in big data analytics, it?s often difficult and time consuming to learn how to access and analyze these big data resources. This is due in part because some of these datasets contain personal information about students, and so are treated as FERPA protected.. In addition, ESS researchers often do not receive such training as part of their graduate programs. This project, carried out by the Institute for Research on Innovation and Science (IRIS), was meant to build capacity in the ESS research community for accessing and analyzing large, restricted datasets by providing training for researchers who are not familiar with big data analytic techniques. Ultimately, the goal is for these researchers to be able to submit successful grant applications to the National Science Foundation for ESS projects using big data. We focused on communities of researchers who traditionally have difficulty accessing this type of training ? women, underserved minorities, and those working at smaller universities, for example.

Over the course of the three-year project, we provided training in ESS big data to 143 researchers, two-thirds of whom were non-white, and 68% of whom were women. The workshops used a model, bespoke dataset created from the existing IRIS dataset as a tool to teach participants how to work with large datasets. The dataset consists of data submitted by IRIS member institutions, tailored for purposes of the workshop to examine the effects of diversity on research teams. This training dataset was a particularly effective tool because it mimics several characteristics of big data that participants might find in their subsequent work, including its location in a virtual data enclave, the inclusion of restricted data, and its provenance from administrative sources.

Participants worked in small groups, each assigned a teaching assistant with knowledge of relevant programming tools, such as Python and SQL. The workshop focused on data exploration, visualization, analysis, and basic statistical modeling techniques that reveal important topics in the dataset. Each group of participants developed a research question based on the composition of the customized IRIS dataset, and proposed approaches to answering it using the data.

We intentionally designed the small groups so that each one included participants from various research fields and career stages; in this way, we encouraged peer teaching as a way to complement the material from instructors and teaching assistants.

The workshops included a session focused on developing, writing and submitting ESS projects using big data for funding from the NSF. More experienced social scientists also made presentations to the group on their career arcs and how developing questions to interrogate big data helped their research.

We had originally planned to hold the workshop at our facilities in Ann Arbor, Michigan, but the COVID pandemic forced us to use video conferencing during the first year of the project. This ended up being more convenient for participants in subsequent years.

At the end of the workshop, each group presented their projects, including any findings coming from their analyses of the training dataset. These presentations were then critiqued by seasoned panelists with experience in social science research and big data.

While we haven?t yet seen the full effects of participation in the workshops, early indications are strong that many participants are leveraging their experiences with our training to further build their abilities to work with big data.

For example, participants were allowed to access the IRIS virtual data enclave for two months after the workshop to refine their abilities to work with the data. Nine workshop participants (two groups of four, and one individual) are still actively using the data enclave for their research.

We also know that many participants are in the process of writing their own papers and developing their own funding proposals. 

We take this as clear evidence that the skills and knowledge we provided in our training workshops under this project have been successful in improving the abilities of participants ? the majority of whom come from underrepresented groups ? to take full advantage of the increasing access to large administrative datasets in their education and social science research.
